## SECTION 4: Key Suppliers Analysis

Maxis Berhad's supplier relationships are integral to its operations as a leading integrated telecommunications provider in Malaysia. The company relies on a diverse set of suppliers for network infrastructure, devices, content, and various operational services. Maxis acknowledges the importance of managing supply chain risks and fostering ethical and sustainable supplier relationships.

### a. List of Largest Suppliers and Supplier Concentration

Maxis's most explicitly detailed suppliers are its related parties, as disclosed in the "Material Contracts" and "Disclosure of Recurrent Related Party Transactions" sections of its Annual Report. While a comprehensive list of all "largest" suppliers by expenditure (beyond related parties) is not provided, the related party transactions offer insight into significant operational dependencies.

**Key Related Party Suppliers by Nature of Transaction (FY2024 & Q1 2025):**

*   **MEASAT Broadcast Network Systems Sdn. Bhd. (MBNS) & Astro Digital 5 Sdn. Bhd. (AD5SB):** Strategic partnership for co-marketing and/or distribution of Astro content products with Maxis connectivity, and supply of specialized resources services.
    *   **FY22 Transaction Value:** RM1,312 million (eKelas® & eKelas® Usahawan) (This is community investment, not supplier transaction directly, but indicates the nature of relationship with Astro affiliates) [AR 2024, p. 48]
    *   **FY23 Transaction Value:** RM125 million (Sales to MBNS) [AR 2024, p. 199], RM11 million (Purchases from MBNS) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **FY24 Transaction Value:** RM90 million (Sales to MBNS) [AR 2024, p. 199], RM8 million (Purchases from MBNS) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **Q1 2025 Transaction Value:** RM19 million (Sales to MBNS) [Q1 2025 FS, p. 12], RM2 million (Purchases from MBNS) [Q1 2025 FS, p. 13]
*   **MEASAT Global Berhad Group (MGB):** Transponder and teleport lease rentals for satellite bandwidth.
    *   **FY23 Transaction Value:** RM30 million (Purchases from MGB) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **FY24 Transaction Value:** RM22 million (Purchases from MGB) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **Q1 2025 Transaction Value:** RM4 million (Purchases from MGB) [Q1 2025 FS, p. 13]
*   **Saudi Telecom Company (stc) & Kuwait Telecommunications Company (stc):** Roaming and international calls.
    *   **FY23 Transaction Value:** RM7 million (Sales to STC) [AR 2024, p. 199], RM8 million (Purchases from STC) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **FY24 Transaction Value:** RM3 million (Sales to STC) [AR 2024, p. 199], RM6 million (Purchases from STC) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **Q1 2025 Transaction Value:** RM1 million (Sales to Kuwait Telecommunications Company) [Q1 2025 FS, p. 12], RM1 million (Purchases from Kuwait Telecommunications Company) [Q1 2025 FS, p. 13]
*   **Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB):** 5G products and services, and shareholder advances.
    *   **FY24 Transaction Value:** RM6 million (Sales to DNB) [AR 2024, p. 200], RM80 million (Purchases from DNB) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **Q1 2025 Transaction Value:** RM3 million (Sales to DNB) [Q1 2025 FS, p. 12], RM39 million (Purchases from DNB) [Q1 2025 FS, p. 13]
*   **Tanjong City Centre Property Management Sdn. Bhd.:** Rental, service charge, property service, and other utility charges.
    *   **FY23 Transaction Value:** RM42 million (Purchases from) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **FY24 Transaction Value:** RM37 million (Purchases from) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **Q1 2025 Transaction Value:** RM9 million (Purchases from) [Q1 2025 FS, p. 13]
*   **SRG Asia Pacific Sdn. Bhd.:** Call handling and telemarketing services.
    *   **FY23 Transaction Value:** RM20 million (Purchases from) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **FY24 Transaction Value:** RM16 million (Purchases from) [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **Q1 2025 Transaction Value:** RM4 million (Purchases from) [Q1 2025 FS, p. 13]

**Supplier Concentration:**
Maxis demonstrates significant supplier concentration with its related parties. These entities, often linked through common ultimate shareholders (Usaha Tegas Sdn. Bhd., Saudi Telecom Company, and Harapan Nusantara Sdn. Bhd.), provide a range of critical services from network infrastructure to content and corporate support. This concentration, while potentially offering synergies and streamlined operations, also presents a risk of dependency. Maxis explicitly states in its "Vendor/Supply Chain Risk" that "A critical failure on vendor's delivery and its supply chain (which includes critical telecommunication equipment and resources) contributed by many aspects may lead to system and network interruptions" [AR 2024, p. 25].

### b. Materials or Components Provided by Each Key Supplier

The types of materials or components provided by key suppliers vary:

*   **Network Infrastructure & Services:**
    *   **Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB):** 5G network access, products, and services. Maxis has a conditional share subscription agreement for an equity stake in DNB and prepayment towards products and services [AR 2024, p. 150]. This is a crucial, evolving relationship for Maxis's 5G strategy.
    *   **MEASAT Global Berhad Group (MGB):** Transponder and teleport lease rentals for satellite bandwidth, essential for backhaul and potentially extending reach to underserved areas [AR 2024, p. 198, 200].
    *   **Network equipment vendors:** While not named, Maxis's CEO mentions "network equipment vendors" as strategic partners for enhancing capabilities and expanding service offerings [AR 2024, p. 7]. The "Technological Milestones" section also notes Maxis's work with Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Huawei, Dell Technologies, Nokia, and China Mobile International for AI-powered networking, 5.5G capabilities, and enterprise digital transformation [AR 2024, p. 34].
*   **Content & Digital Solutions:**
    *   **MEASAT Broadcast Network Systems Sdn. Bhd. (MBNS) & Astro Digital 5 Sdn. Bhd. (AD5SB):** Content for co-marketing and distribution with Maxis's fibre services [AR 2024, p. 198].
*   **Customer Service & Support:**
    *   **SRG Asia Pacific Sdn. Bhd.:** Call handling and telemarketing services, supporting customer acquisition and retention efforts [AR 2024, p. 200].
*   **Corporate & Property Services:**
    *   **Tanjong City Centre Property Management Sdn. Bhd.:** Rental, service charges, property services, and utility charges for operational sites [AR 2024, p. 200].
    *   **UTSB Management Sdn. Bhd. & Maxis Communications Berhad:** Corporate management services and corporate support services [AR 2024, p. 199-200].

### c. Supplier's Position in the Value Chain and Margin Capture

Maxis primarily operates as a B2C (Mobile, Home) and B2B (Enterprise) integrated telecommunications provider. Its key suppliers generally fall into a B2B relationship with Maxis.

*   **B2B Suppliers (to Maxis):** This category includes network equipment vendors, infrastructure providers (like DNB and MEASAT Global), and IT/software providers (e.g., SAP for S4/HANA transition). These suppliers capture margins at the wholesale or infrastructure level.
*   **B2B2C Partnerships:**
    *   **MBNS (Astro):** Maxis's collaboration with Astro is a B2B2C model. Astro (MBNS) provides content to Maxis (B2B), which Maxis then bundles with its fibre services for end-consumers (B2C). Maxis and MBNS co-market these offers, implying a shared revenue or cost-sharing arrangement. The "Set Charges" payable by Maxis to MBNS for Astro's content service and vice-versa for Maxis's fibre service indicate a negotiated margin split [AR 2024, p. 198].
*   **Margin Capture:** Specific margin capture by individual suppliers is not disclosed. However, Maxis's consistent focus on "cost discipline" and "operational efficiencies" (Q4 2024 TS, slide 9; Q1 2025 TS, slide 9) suggests active management of supplier costs to protect its own margins. The "Vendor/Supply Chain Risk" section highlights "Purchase price reductions through volume and commercial competitiveness" as an opportunity, indicating Maxis's efforts to negotiate favorable terms [AR 2024, p. 25].

The company's supplier relationships, particularly with related parties, form a significant part of its operational framework.

## SECTION 4: Key Suppliers Analysis

Maxis Berhad's supplier relationships are crucial for its operations as a leading integrated telecommunications provider in Malaysia. The company's supply chain encompasses various services, from network infrastructure and maintenance to content delivery and corporate support. Maxis emphasizes managing supply chain risks and fostering ethical and sustainable supplier relationships.

### a. List of Largest Suppliers and Supplier Concentration

Maxis provides detailed information on its related party suppliers, which represent a significant portion of its overall procurement. While specific non-related major suppliers are not individually named with transaction values, the collective expenditure on local versus foreign suppliers is disclosed.

## SECTION 4: Key Suppliers Analysis

Maxis Berhad's supplier relationships are crucial for its operations as a leading integrated telecommunications provider in Malaysia. The company's supply chain encompasses various services, from network infrastructure and maintenance to content delivery and corporate support. Maxis emphasizes managing supply chain risks and fostering ethical and sustainable supplier relationships.

### a. List of Largest Suppliers and Supplier Concentration

Maxis provides detailed information on its related party suppliers, which represent a significant portion of its overall procurement. While specific non-related major suppliers are not individually named with transaction values, the collective expenditure on local versus foreign suppliers is disclosed.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Maxis has secured its position as a leading integrated telecommunications provider in Malaysia, navigating a dynamic and highly competitive market. The company's focus on strategic execution, customer experience, operational efficiency, and talent development has driven its financial performance and market standing.

### a. Largest Suppliers and Supplier Concentration

Maxis’s most significant supplier relationships, as detailed in its financial reports, are primarily with **related parties**. These relationships are extensive, covering various critical aspects of its business. Key related party suppliers include:

*   **Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB)**: The sole wholesale 5G network provider in Malaysia, now transitioning to a dual network model. Maxis has an equity stake and significant prepayments with DNB, making it a critical supplier for future 5G services. [AR 2024, p. 150-151; Q4 2024 FS, p. 25; Q1 2025 FS, p. 25]
*   **MEASAT Broadcast Network Systems Sdn. Bhd. (MBNS) / Astro Digital 5 Sdn. Bhd. (AD5SB)**: Provides content for co-marketing and distribution with Maxis's fibre services. [AR 2024, p. 198-199]
*   **MEASAT Global Berhad Group (MGB)**: Supplies transponder and teleport lease rentals for satellite bandwidth. [AR 2024, p. 200]
*   **Saudi Telecom Company (stc) / Kuwait Telecommunications Company (stc)**: Engaged in roaming and international call services. [AR 2024, p. 199-200]
*   **Tanjong City Centre Property Management Sdn. Bhd.**: Provides rental, service charges, property services, and utility charges for Maxis's operational sites. [AR 2024, p. 200]
*   **SRG Asia Pacific Sdn. Bhd.**: Delivers call handling and telemarketing services. [AR 2024, p. 200]
*   **UTSB Management Sdn. Bhd. / Maxis Communications Berhad**: Offers corporate management and support services. [AR 2024, p. 199-200]

**Supplier Concentration:** Maxis exhibits a high degree of supplier concentration with its related parties. These entities are often linked through common ultimate shareholders, such as Usaha Tegas Sdn. Bhd. and Saudi Telecom Company. This concentration, while potentially offering synergistic benefits and streamlined operations due to shared governance and objectives, also introduces a significant **dependency risk**. Maxis explicitly acknowledges this in its "Vendor/Supply Chain Risk" disclosure, noting that "A critical failure on vendor's delivery and its supply chain (which includes critical telecommunication equipment and resources) contributed by many aspects may lead to system and network interruptions" [AR 2024, p. 25].

### b. Materials or Components Provided by Each Key Supplier

The types of materials and services procured from these key suppliers are diverse and essential to Maxis's integrated service offerings:

*   **Network Infrastructure & Services:**
    *   **Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB):** Provides access to the 5G network, including related products and services. Maxis's significant investment and prepayment in DNB underscore its critical role in Maxis's 5G rollout and future strategy. [AR 2024, p. 150-151]
    *   **MEASAT Global Berhad Group (MGB):** Supplies transponder and teleport lease rentals, crucial for satellite-based connectivity and potentially expanding network reach, especially in underserved areas. [AR 2024, p. 198, 200]
    *   **Unnamed Network Equipment Vendors:** Maxis's CEO acknowledges partnerships with "network equipment vendors" and "major tech companies" (e.g., Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Huawei, Dell Technologies, Nokia, China Mobile International) for advanced networking, 5.5G capabilities, and enterprise digital transformation. These partnerships are vital for maintaining network quality and technological leadership. [AR 2024, p. 7, 34]
*   **Content & Digital Solutions:**
    *   **MEASAT Broadcast Network Systems Sdn. Bhd. (MBNS) / Astro Digital 5 Sdn. Bhd. (AD5SB):** Delivers content for Maxis's bundled offerings, particularly with its fibre services, enhancing customer value propositions. [AR 2024, p. 198]
*   **Customer Service & Operational Support:**
    *   **SRG Asia Pacific Sdn. Bhd.:** Provides essential call handling and telemarketing services, directly impacting customer interaction and acquisition strategies. [AR 2024, p. 200]
*   **Corporate & Property Services:**
    *   **Tanjong City Centre Property Management Sdn. Bhd.:** Manages property-related expenses, including rentals, service charges, and utilities for Maxis's extensive operational footprint. [AR 2024, p. 200]
    *   **UTSB Management Sdn. Bhd. / Maxis Communications Berhad:** Offers corporate management and support services, contributing to the overall administrative efficiency of the Group. [AR 2024, p. 199-200]

### c. Supplier's Position in the Value Chain and Margin Capture

Maxis primarily operates in **B2C (Business-to-Consumer)** and **B2B (Business-to-Business)** segments as an integrated telco. Its key suppliers generally function in a **B2B** capacity relative to Maxis.

*   **B2B Suppliers:** The majority of Maxis's key suppliers, including network equipment vendors, infrastructure providers (DNB, MEASAT Global), and corporate service providers, operate in a pure B2B model, selling directly to Maxis. Their margin capture occurs at this wholesale or enterprise service level.
*   **B2B2C Partnerships:** The relationship with **MBNS (Astro)** exemplifies a B2B2C model. Astro provides content to Maxis (B2B), which Maxis then bundles with its fibre services for end-consumers (B2C). The "Amended and Restated Fibre Co-Marketing Agreement" and "Supplemental Agreement" with MBNS outline "Set Charges" payable by both parties, indicating a structured mechanism for revenue sharing and margin allocation within this integrated offering [AR 2024, p. 198]. This suggests a negotiated split of the value created, rather than a simple buy-and-resell model.

While specific supplier margin capture rates are not disclosed, Maxis's consistent emphasis on "cost discipline" and "operational efficiencies" (Q4 2024 TS, slide 9; Q1 2025 TS, slide 9) suggests an active approach to managing procurement costs to protect and enhance its own profitability. The identification of "Purchase price reductions through volume and commercial competitiveness" as an opportunity in its risk management framework further supports this [AR 2024, p. 25].
